001package squidpony;
002
003import regexodus.*;
004import squidpony.squidmath.*;
005
006import java.io.Serializable;
007import java.util.ArrayList;
008import java.util.Collection;
009import java.util.Iterator;
010import java.util.Map;
011
012import static squidpony.Maker.makeList;
013import static squidpony.Maker.makeOM;
014
015/**
016 * A text processing class that can swap out occurrences of special keywords and replace them with randomly-selected
017 * synonyms. For example, this can take {@code "By the light`adj` fire`noun` in my heart, I will vanquish thee!"}, which
018 * has the keywords {@code light`adj`} and {@code fire`noun`}, and could produce
019 * {@code "By the shimmering inferno in my heart, I will vanquish thee!"} on one run, and
020 * {@code "By the gleaming conflagration in my heart, I will vanquish thee!"} on another. This can also generate some
021 * plant names and basic descriptions of potions, as well as make some text sound like {@link #ORK}. 
022 * <br>
023 * Created by Tommy Ettinger on 5/23/2016.
024 */
025public class Thesaurus implements Serializable{
026    private static final long serialVersionUID = 3387639905758074640L;
027    protected static final Pattern wordMatch = Pattern.compile("([\\pL`]+|@)"),
028            similarFinder = Pattern.compile(".*?\\b(\\w\\w\\w\\w).*?{\\@1}.*$", "ui");
029    public OrderedMap<CharSequence, GapShuffler<String>> mappings;
030    public ArrayList<FakeLanguageGen.Alteration> alterations = new ArrayList<>(4);
031    public SilkRNG rng;
032    protected GapShuffler<String> plantTermShuffler, fruitTermShuffler, nutTermShuffler, flowerTermShuffler,
033            potionTermShuffler, vegetableTermShuffler;
034    public FakeLanguageGen defaultLanguage = FakeLanguageGen.SIMPLISH;
035    public transient ArrayList<FakeLanguageGen> randomLanguages = new ArrayList<>(2);
036    public transient String latestGenerated = "Nationia";
037    /**
038     * Constructs a new Thesaurus with an unseeded RNG used to shuffle word order.
039     */
040    public Thesaurus()
041    {
042        mappings = new OrderedMap<>(256, Hashers.caseInsensitiveStringHasher);
043        rng = new SilkRNG();
044        addKnownCategories();
045    }
046
047    /**
048     * Constructs a new Thesaurus, seeding its RNG (used to shuffle word order) with the next long from the given RNG.
049     * @param rng an RNG that will only be used to get one long (for seeding this class' RNG)
050     */
051    public Thesaurus(IRNG rng)
052    {
053        this(rng.nextLong());
054    }
055
056    /**
057     * Constructs a new Thesaurus, seeding its RNG (used to shuffle word order) with shuffleSeed.
058     * @param shuffleSeed a long for seeding this class' RNG
059     */
060    public Thesaurus(long shuffleSeed)
061    {
062        mappings = new OrderedMap<>(256, Hashers.caseInsensitiveStringHasher);
063        this.rng = new SilkRNG(shuffleSeed);
064        addKnownCategories();
065    }
066
067
068    /**
069     * Constructs a new Thesaurus, seeding its RNG (used to shuffle word order) with shuffleSeed.
070     * @param shuffleSeed a String for seeding this class' RNG
071     */
072    public Thesaurus(String shuffleSeed)
073    {
074        this(CrossHash.hash64(shuffleSeed));
075    }
076
077    /**
078     * Changes the sequences for all groups of synonyms this can produce, effectively turning this Thesaurus into a
079     * different version that knows all the same synonyms and categories but will produce different results.
080     * @param state any long; will be given to {@link SilkRNG#setState(long)}
081     */
082    public void refresh(long state)
083    {
084        refresh((int)(state & 0xFFFFFFFFL), (int)(state >>> 32));
085    }
086
087    /**
088     * Changes the sequences for all groups of synonyms this can produce, effectively turning this Thesaurus into a
089     * different version that knows all the same synonyms and categories but will produce different results.
090     * @param stateA any int; the first part of the state of a {@link SilkRNG}
091     * @param stateB any int; the second part of the state of a {@link SilkRNG}
092     */
093    public void refresh(int stateA, int stateB)
094    {
095        this.rng.setState(stateA, stateB);
096        final int sz = mappings.size();
097        for (int i = 0; i < sz; i++) {
098            mappings.getAt(i).setRNG(rng, true);
099        }
100    }
101
102    public Thesaurus addReplacement(CharSequence before, String after)
103    {
104        mappings.put(before, new GapShuffler<>(after));
105        return this;
106    }
107
108    /**
109     * Allows this Thesaurus to replace a specific keyword, typically containing multiple backtick characters
110     * ({@code `}) so it can't be confused with a "real word," with one of the words in synonyms (chosen in shuffled
111     * order). The backtick is the only punctuation character that this class' word matcher considers part of a word,
112     * both for this reason and because it is rarely used in English text.
113     * @param keyword a word (typically containing backticks, {@code `}) that will be replaced by a word from synonyms
114     * @param synonyms a Collection of lower-case Strings with similar meaning and the same part of speech
115     * @return this for chaining
116     */
117    public Thesaurus addCategory(String keyword, Collection<String> synonyms)
118    {
119        if(synonyms.isEmpty())
120            return this;
121        GapShuffler<String> shuffler = new GapShuffler<>(synonyms, rng, true);
122        mappings.put(keyword, shuffler);
123        return this;
124    }
125
126    /**
127     * Adds several pre-made categories to this Thesaurus' known categories, but won't cause it to try to replace normal
128     * words with synonyms (only categories, which contain backticks in the name). The keywords this currently knows,
129     * and the words it will replace those keywords with, are:
130     * <br>
131     * <ul>
132     *     <li>calm`adj` : calm, harmonious, peaceful, placid, pleasant, serene, tranquil</li>
133     *     <li>calm`noun` : calm, harmony, kindness, peace, serenity, tranquility</li>
134     *     <li>org`noun` : association, brotherhood, fellowship, foundation, fraternity, group, guild, order, partnership</li>
135     *     <li>org`nouns` : associations, brotherhoods, fellowships, foundations, fraternities, groups, guilds, orders, partnerships</li>
136     *     <li>empire`adj` : ascendant, dynastic, emir's, hegemonic, imperial, king's, lordly, monarchic, prince's, regal, royal, sultan's</li>
137     *     <li>empire`noun` : ascendancy, commonwealth, dominion, dynasty, emirate, empire, hegemony, imperium, kingdom, monarchy, sultanate, triumvirate</li>

139     *     <li>emperor`noun` : emir, emperor, king, lord, pharaoh, ruler, sultan</li>

144     *     <li>union`noun` : alliance, coalition, confederacy, confederation, congress, faction, federation, league, republic, union</li>
145     *     <li>union`nouns` : alliances, coalitions, confederacies, confederations, congresses, factions, federations, leagues, republics, unions</li>
146     *     <li>militia`noun` : fighters, front, irregulars, liberators, militants, militia, rebellion, resistance, warriors</li>
147     *     <li>militia`nouns` : fighters, fronts, irregulars, liberators, militants, militias, rebellions, resistances, warriors</li>

162     *     <li>forest`noun` : copse, forest, glen, greenery, grove, jungle, nature, woodland</li>

164     *     <li>shaman`nouns` : animists, druids, shamans, wardens</li>

251     * There are also terms, which typically produce multiple words procedurally and may use {@link #defaultLanguage}.
252     * See {@link #makePlantName()}, {@link #makeFruitName()}, {@link #makeNutName()}, {@link #makeFlowerName()},
253     * {@link #makeVegetableName()}, and {@link #makePotionDescription()} for more info and examples.
254     * <li>
255     *     <li>plant`term` : @'s color`adj`\tleaf`noun`, @'s color`adj` flower`noun`, @'s color`adj` tree`noun`, @'s flower`noun`, @'s ground`noun`\tleaf`noun`, @'s sensory`adj`-leaf`noun`, @'s shape`adj` flower`noun`, @'s tree`noun`, color`adj` flower`noun`, color`adj` flower`noun` of @, color`adj` fruit`noun` tree`noun`, color`adj` nut`noun` tree`noun`, color`adj`-leaf`noun` flower`noun`, color`adj`-vegetable`noun` tree`noun`, flavor`adj` fruit`noun` tree`noun`, flavor`adj` nut`noun` tree`noun`, flavor`noun`\tleaf`noun` tree`noun`, flower`noun` of @, ground`noun`\tflower`noun`, ground`noun`\tleaf`noun`, ground`noun`\tleaf`noun` of @, ground`noun`\tvegetable`noun`, leaf`noun` of @, sensory`adj` flower`noun` of @, sensory`adj` flower`noun`-flower`noun`, sensory`adj` tree`noun` of @, sensory`adj` tree`noun`-tree`noun`, sensory`adj`-leaf`noun` flower`noun`, sensory`adj`-leaf`noun` tree`noun`, shape`adj` flower`noun`, shape`adj`-fruit`noun` tree`noun`, shape`adj`-leaf`noun` flower`noun`, shape`adj`-leaf`noun` tree`noun`, shape`adj`-vegetable`noun` tree`noun`, vegetable`noun`-leaf`noun` tree`noun`</li>
256     *     <li>fruit`term` : @'s color`adj` fruit`noun`, @'s flavor`adj` fruit`noun`, @'s fruit`noun`, color`adj` fruit`noun`, color`adj` fruit`noun` of @, color`adj` fruit`noun`-fruit`noun`, flavor`adj` fruit`noun`, flavor`adj` fruit`noun` of @, flavor`adj` fruit`noun`-fruit`noun`, fruit`noun` of @, shape`adj` fruit`noun`, shape`adj` fruit`noun`-fruit`noun`</li>
257     *     <li>nut`term` : @'s color`adj` nut`noun`, @'s flavor`adj` nut`noun`, @'s nut`noun`, color`adj` nut`noun`, color`adj` nut`noun` of @, flavor`adj` nut`noun`, nut`noun` of @, sensory`adj` nut`noun`</li>
258     *     <li>vegetable`term` : @'s color`adj` vegetable`noun`, @'s flavor`adj` vegetable`noun`, @'s vegetable`noun`, @'s vegetable`noun`-vegetable`noun`, color`adj` sensory`adj` vegetable`noun`, color`adj` vegetable`noun`, color`adj` vegetable`noun` of @, color`adj` vegetable`noun`-vegetable`noun`, flavor`adj` vegetable`noun`, flavor`adj` vegetable`noun`-vegetable`noun`, sensory`adj` shape`adj` vegetable`noun`, sensory`adj` vegetable`noun`, sensory`adj` vegetable`noun`-vegetable`noun`, shape`adj` color`adj` vegetable`noun`, shape`adj` vegetable`noun`, shape`adj` vegetable`noun`-vegetable`noun`, vegetable`noun` of @</li>
259     *     <li>flower`term` : @'s color`adj` flower`noun`, @'s flower`noun`, @'s shape`adj` flower`noun`, color`adj` flower`noun`, color`adj` flower`noun` of @, color`adj`-leaf`noun` flower`noun`, flower`noun` of @, ground`noun`\tflower`noun`, sensory`adj` flower`noun` of @, sensory`adj` flower`noun`-flower`noun`, sensory`adj`-leaf`noun` flower`noun`, shape`adj` flower`noun`, shape`adj`-leaf`noun` flower`noun`</li>
260     *     <li>potion`term` : a bottle`adj` bottle`noun` containing a few drops of a color`adj` liquid`noun`, a bottle`adj` bottle`noun` filled with a color`adj` liquid`noun`, a bottle`adj` bottle`noun` filled with a liquid`adj` color`adj` liquid`noun`, a bottle`adj` bottle`noun` half-filled with a liquid`adj` color`adj` liquid`noun`, a calabash`noun` filled with a color`adj` liquid`noun`</li>
261     * </ul>
262     * Capitalizing the first letter in the keyword where it appears in text you call process() on will capitalize the
263     * first letter of the produced fake word. Capitalizing the second letter will capitalize the whole produced fake
264     * word. This applies only per-instance of each keyword; it won't change the internally-stored list of words.
265     * @return this for chaining
266     */
267    public Thesaurus addKnownCategories()
268    {
269        for(Map.Entry<String, ArrayList<String>> kv : categories.entrySet())
270        {
271            addCategory(kv.getKey(), kv.getValue());
272        }
273        plantTermShuffler =     mappings.get("plant`term`");
274        fruitTermShuffler =     mappings.get("fruit`term`");
275        nutTermShuffler =       mappings.get("nut`term`");
276        vegetableTermShuffler = mappings.get("vegetable`term`");
277        flowerTermShuffler =    mappings.get("flower`term`");
278        potionTermShuffler =    mappings.get("potion`term`");
279        return this;
280    }
281
282    /**
283     * Given an archive String saved by {@link #archiveCategories()} (probably from another version of SquidLib), this
284     * makes the Thesaurus class act like it did in that archive, assuming the {@link #rng} is seeded the same. This
285     * modifies the {@link #mappings} field and the {@link #categories}, {@link #adjective}, {@link #noun}, and
286     * {@link #nouns} static fields, so it can affect other Thesaurus objects produced later (it won't change
287     * previously-made ones, probably).
288     * <br>
289     * If you didn't have an archive of the categories from some version of SquidLib, you can download one of the small
290     * files from <a href="https://github.com/yellowstonegames/SquidLib/tree/master/archives">the 'archives' folder of
291     * the SquidLib repo</a>; there's an archive that acts as a snapshot of SquidLib 3.0.0's Thesaurus class, for
292     * instance. This method expects files saved with a particular format, and SquidLib also supports a different format
293     * (used with {@link #addArchivedCategoriesAlternate(String)}). The files with the correct format for this end in
294     * {@code .squid.txt}. If you save the 3.0.0 {@code .squid.txt} archive in a libGDX application's assets folder, you
295     * can reload the 3.0.0 definitions into a Thesaurus called {@code myThesaurus} with:
296     * <br>
297     * {@code myThesaurus.addArchivedCategories(Gdx.files.internal("Thesaurus-3-0-0.squid.txt").readString("UTF-8"));}
298     * 
299     * @param archive an archived String of categories produced by {@link #archiveCategories()}
300     * @return this Thesaurus, but static state of the class will also be modified so this may affect other Thesaurus objects
301     */
302    public Thesaurus addArchivedCategories(String archive){
303        final OrderedMap<String, ArrayList<String>> cat = Converters.convertOrderedMap(
304                Converters.convertString,
305                Converters.convertArrayList(Converters.convertString)
306        ).restore(archive);
307        
308        mappings.clear();
309        
310        categories.clear();
311        categories.putAll(cat);
312        
313        adjective.clear();
314        adjective.putAll(cat);
315        
316        noun.clear();
317        noun.putAll(cat);
318        
319        nouns.clear();
320        nouns.putAll(cat);
321        
322        Iterator<String> it = adjective.keySet().iterator();
323        while (it.hasNext()){
324            if(!it.next().contains("`adj`"))
325                it.remove();
326        }
327        it = noun.keySet().iterator();
328        while (it.hasNext()){
329            if(!it.next().contains("`noun`"))
330                it.remove();
331        }
332        it = nouns.keySet().iterator();
333        while (it.hasNext()){
334            if(!it.next().contains("`nouns`"))
335                it.remove();
336        }
337
338        for(Map.Entry<String, ArrayList<String>> kv : categories.entrySet())
339        {
340            addCategory(kv.getKey(), kv.getValue());
341        }
342        plantTermShuffler =  mappings.get("plant`term`");
343        fruitTermShuffler =  mappings.get("fruit`term`");
344        nutTermShuffler =    mappings.get("nut`term`");
345        vegetableTermShuffler = mappings.get("vegetable`term`");
346        flowerTermShuffler = mappings.get("flower`term`");
347        potionTermShuffler = mappings.get("potion`term`");
348
349        return this;
350    }
351
352    /**
353     * Given an archive String saved by {@link #archiveCategoriesAlternate()} (probably from another version of
354     * SquidLib), this makes the Thesaurus class act like it did in that archive, assuming the {@link #rng} is seeded
355     * the same and uses the same algorithm/RandomnessSource. This modifies the {@link #mappings} field and the
356     * {@link #categories}, {@link #adjective}, {@link #noun}, and {@link #nouns} static fields, so it can affect other
357     * Thesaurus objects produced later (it won't change previously-made ones, probably).
358     * <br>
359     * If you didn't have an archive of the categories from some version of SquidLib, you can download one of the small
360     * files from <a href="https://github.com/yellowstonegames/SquidLib/tree/master/archives">the 'archives' folder of the
361     * SquidLib repo</a>; there's an archive that acts as a snapshot of SquidLib 3.0.0's Thesaurus class, for instance.
362     * The files that use this method's format end in {@code .alt.txt}, while the other format uses {@code .squid.txt}.
363     * If you save the 3.0.0 archive in a libGDX application's assets folder, you can reload the 3.0.0 definitions into
364     * a Thesaurus called {@code myThesaurus} with:
365     * <br>
366     * {@code myThesaurus.addArchivedCategoriesAlternate(Gdx.files.internal("Thesaurus-3-0-0.alt.txt").readString("UTF-8"));}
367     *
368     * @param archive an archived String of categories produced by {@link #archiveCategoriesAlternate()}
369     * @return this Thesaurus, but static state of the class will also be modified so this may affect other Thesaurus objects
370     */
371    public Thesaurus addArchivedCategoriesAlternate(String archive){
372        String[] lines = archive.split("\r?\n");
373        mappings.clear();
374
375        categories.clear();
376        for (int i = 0, n = lines.length; i < n; i++) {
377            int idx = lines[i].indexOf('\u00A0');
378            categories.put(lines[i].substring(0, idx), Maker.makeList(StringKit.split(lines[i].substring(idx + 1), "\u00A0")));
379        }
380
381        adjective.clear();
382        adjective.putAll(categories);
383
384        noun.clear();
385        noun.putAll(categories);
386
387        nouns.clear();
388        nouns.putAll(categories);
389
390        Iterator<String> it = adjective.keySet().iterator();
391        while (it.hasNext()){
392            if(!it.next().contains("`adj`"))
393                it.remove();
394        }
395        it = noun.keySet().iterator();
396        while (it.hasNext()){
397            if(!it.next().contains("`noun`"))
398                it.remove();
399        }
400        it = nouns.keySet().iterator();
401        while (it.hasNext()){
402            if(!it.next().contains("`nouns`"))
403                it.remove();
404        }
405
406        for(Map.Entry<String, ArrayList<String>> kv : categories.entrySet())
407        {
408            addCategory(kv.getKey(), kv.getValue());
409        }
410        plantTermShuffler =  mappings.get("plant`term`");
411        fruitTermShuffler =  mappings.get("fruit`term`");
412        nutTermShuffler =    mappings.get("nut`term`");
413        vegetableTermShuffler = mappings.get("vegetable`term`");
414        flowerTermShuffler = mappings.get("flower`term`");
415        potionTermShuffler = mappings.get("potion`term`");
416
417        return this;
418    }
419
420    /**
421     * Adds a large list of words pre-generated by FakeLanguageGen and hand-picked for fitness, and makes them
422     * accessible with a keyword based on the language. The keywords this currently knows:
423     * <br>
424     * "lovecraft`pre`", "english`pre`", "greek_romanized`pre`",
425     * "greek_authentic`pre`", "french`pre`", "russian_romanized`pre`",
426     * "russian_authentic`pre`", "japanese_romanized`pre`", "swahili`pre`",
427     * "somali`pre`", "hindi_romanized`pre`", "arabic_romanized`pre`",
428     * "inuktitut`pre`", "norse`pre`", "nahuatl`pre`", "mongolian`pre`",
429     * "fantasy`pre`", "fancy_fantasy`pre`", "goblin`pre`", "elf`pre`",
430     * "demonic`pre`", "infernal`pre`", "simplish`pre`", "alien_a`pre`",
431     * "korean_romanized`pre`", "alien_e`pre`", "alien_i`pre`", "alien_o`pre`",
432     * "alien_u`pre`", "dragon`pre`", "kobold`pre`", "insect`pre`", "maori`pre`",
433     * "spanish`pre`", "deep_speech`pre`", "norse_simplified`pre`",
434     * "hletkip`pre`", "ancient_egyptian`pre`", "crow`pre`", "imp`pre`",
435     * "malay`pre`", "celestial`pre`", "chinese_romanized`pre`",
436     * "cherokee_romanized`pre`", "vietnamese`pre`"
437     * <br>
438     * These correspond to similarly-named fields in {@link FakeLanguageGen}, just without {@code `pre`}; for instance
439     * {@code "cherokee_romanized`pre`"} corresponds to {@link FakeLanguageGen#CHEROKEE_ROMANIZED}. You can use these
440     * same keywords with {@code `gen`} instead of {@code `pre`} to generate at runtime based on the current RNG state,
441     * instead of using one of several pre-generated words, and doing that does not require addFakeWords() to be used.
442     * <br>
443     * Capitalizing the first letter in the keyword where it appears in text you call process() on will capitalize the
444     * first letter of the produced fake word, which is often desirable for things like place names. Capitalizing the
445     * second letter will capitalize the whole produced fake word. This applies only per-instance of each keyword; it
446     * won't change the internally-stored list of words.
447     * @return this for chaining
448     */
449    public Thesaurus addFakeWords()
450    {
451        //long state = rng.getState();
452        for(Map.Entry<CharSequence, FakeLanguageGen> kv : languages.entrySet())
453        {
454            ArrayList<String> words = new ArrayList<>(16);
455            for (int i = 0; i < 16; i++) {
456                words.add(kv.getValue().word(rng, false, rng.between(2, 4)));
457            }
458            addCategory(StringKit.replace(kv.getKey(), "`gen", "`pre"), words);
459        }
460        //rng.setState(state);
461        return this;
462    }
463
464    private StringBuilder modify(CharSequence text)
465    {
466        Matcher m;
467        StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder(text);
468        Replacer.StringBuilderBuffer tb, working = Replacer.wrap(sb);
469        StringBuilder tmp;
470        boolean found;
471        FakeLanguageGen.Alteration alt;
472        for (int a = 0; a < alterations.size(); a++) {
473            alt = alterations.get(a);
474            tmp = working.sb;
475            tb = Replacer.wrap(new StringBuilder(tmp.length()));
476            m = alt.replacer.getPattern().matcher(tmp);
477
478            found = false;
479            while (true) {
480                if (rng.nextDouble() < alt.chance) {
481                    if (!Replacer.replaceStep(m, alt.replacer.getSubstitution(), tb))
482                        break;
483                    found = true;
484                } else {
485                    if (!m.find())
486                        break;
487                    found = true;
488                    m.getGroup(MatchResult.PREFIX, tb);
489                    m.getGroup(MatchResult.MATCH, tb);
490                    m.setTarget(m, MatchResult.SUFFIX);
491                }
492            }
493            if (found) {
494                m.getGroup(MatchResult.TARGET, tb);
495                working = tb;
496            }
497        }
498        return working.sb;
499
500    }
501    /**
502     * Given a String, StringBuilder, or other CharSequence that should contain words this knows synonyms for, this
503     * replaces each occurrence of such a known word with one of its synonyms, leaving unknown words untouched. Words
504     * that were learned together as synonyms with addSynonyms() will be replaced in such a way that an individual
505     * replacement word should not occur too close to a previous occurrence of the same word; that is, replacing the
506     * text "You fiend! You demon! You despoiler of creation; devil made flesh!", where "fiend", "demon", and "devil"
507     * are all synonyms, would never produce a string that contained "fiend" as the replacement for all three of those.
508     * @param text a CharSequence, such as a String, that contains words in the source language
509     * @return a String of the translated text.
510     */
511    public String process(CharSequence text)
512    {
513//        Replacer rep = wordMatch.replacer(new SynonymSubstitution());
514        //String t = rep.replace(text);
515        Matcher m = wordMatch.matcher(text);
516        Substitution substitution = new SynonymSubstitution();
517        Replacer.StringBuilderBuffer dest = Replacer.wrap(new StringBuilder(text.length()));
518        while (m.find()) {
519            if (m.start() > 0) m.getGroup(MatchResult.PREFIX, dest);
520            substitution.appendSubstitution(m, dest);
521            m.setTarget(m, MatchResult.SUFFIX);
522        }
523        m.getGroup(MatchResult.TARGET, dest);
524
525        m.setTarget(dest.sb);
526        dest.sb.setLength(0);
527        while (m.find()) {
528            if (m.start() > 0) m.getGroup(MatchResult.PREFIX, dest);
529            substitution.appendSubstitution(m, dest);
530            m.setTarget(m, MatchResult.SUFFIX);
531        }
532        m.getGroup(MatchResult.TARGET, dest);
533
534        if(alterations.isEmpty())
535            return StringKit.replace(StringKit.correctABeforeVowel(dest.sb), "\t", "");
536        else
537            return StringKit.replace(modify(StringKit.correctABeforeVowel(dest.sb)), "\t", "");
538    }
539
540    public String lookup(String word)
541    {
542        if(word.isEmpty())
543            return word;
544        if("@".equals(word))
545        {
546            return defaultLanguage.word(rng, true, rng.between(2, 4));
547        }
548        String word2 = word.toLowerCase();
549        if(mappings.containsKey(word2))
550        {
551            String nx = mappings.get(word2).next();
552            if(nx.isEmpty())
553                return nx;
554            if(word.length() > 1 && Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(1)))
555                return nx.toUpperCase();
556            if(Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(0)))
557            {
558                return Character.toUpperCase(nx.charAt(0)) + nx.substring(1);
559            }
560            return nx;
561        }
562        else if(languages.containsKey(word2))
563        {
564            if(word.length() > 1 && Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(1)))
565                return languages.get(word2).word(rng, false, rng.between(2, 4)).toUpperCase();
566            if(Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(0)))
567            {
568                return languages.get(word2).word(rng, true, rng.between(2, 4));
569            }
570            return languages.get(word2).word(rng, false, rng.between(2, 4));
571        }
572        return word;
573    }
574
575    private class SynonymSubstitution implements Substitution
576    {
577        private final StringBuilder temp = new StringBuilder(64);
578        @Override
579        public void appendSubstitution(MatchResult match, TextBuffer dest) {
580            //dest.append(lookup(match.group(0)));
581            temp.setLength(0);
582            match.getGroup(0, temp);
583            writeLookup(dest, temp);
584        }
585    }
586
587    private void writeLookup(TextBuffer dest, StringBuilder word) {
588        if(word == null || word.length() <= 0)
589            return;
590        if(word.charAt(0) == '@' && word.length() == 1)
591        {
592            dest.append(defaultLanguage.word(rng, true, rng.between(2, 4)));
593            return;
594        }
595        else if(mappings.containsKey(word))
596        {
597            String nx = mappings.get(word).next();
598            if(nx.isEmpty())
599                return;
600            if(word.length() > 1 && Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(1)))
601            {
602                dest.append(nx.toUpperCase());
603                return;
604            }
605            if(Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(0)))
606            {
607                dest.append(Character.toUpperCase(nx.charAt(0)));
608                dest.append(nx.substring(1));
609                return;
610            }
611            dest.append(nx);
612            return;
613        }
614        else if(languages.containsKey(word))
615        {
616            if(word.length() > 1 && Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(1)))
617            {
618                dest.append(languages.get(word).word(rng, false, rng.between(2, 4)).toUpperCase());
619            }
620            else if(Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(0)))
621            {
622                dest.append(languages.get(word).word(rng, true, rng.between(2, 4)));
623            }
624            else
625            {
626                dest.append(languages.get(word).word(rng, false, rng.between(2, 4)));
627            }
628            return;
629        }
630        else if(numbers.containsKey(word))
631        {
632            if(word.length() > 1 && Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(1)))
633            {
634                dest.append(numberWordInRange(2, numbers.get(word)).toUpperCase());
635            }
636            else if(Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(0)))
637            {
638                String w = numberWordInRange(2, numbers.get(word));
639                dest.append(Character.toUpperCase(w.charAt(0)));
640                dest.append(w.substring(1));
641            }
642            else
643            {
644                dest.append(numberWordInRange(2, numbers.get(word)));
645            }
646            return;
647        }
648        else if(numberAdjectives.containsKey(word))
649        {
650            if(word.length() > 1 && Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(1)))
651            {
652                dest.append(numberAdjectiveInRange(2, numberAdjectives.get(word)).toUpperCase());
653            }
654            else if(Category.Lu.contains(word.charAt(0)))
655            {
656                String w = numberAdjectiveInRange(2, numberAdjectives.get(word));
657                dest.append(Character.toUpperCase(w.charAt(0)));
658                dest.append(w.substring(1));
659            }
660            else
661            {
662                dest.append(numberAdjectiveInRange(2, numberAdjectives.get(word)));
663            }
664            return;
665        }
666        if(dest instanceof Replacer.StringBuilderBuffer)
667        {
668            ((Replacer.StringBuilderBuffer)dest).sb.append(word);
669        }
670        else
671            dest.append(word.toString());
672
673    }
674
675    private class RandomLanguageSubstitution implements Substitution
676    {
677        @Override
678        public void appendSubstitution(MatchResult match, TextBuffer dest) {
679            FakeLanguageGen lang = FakeLanguageGen.randomLanguage(rng.nextLong());
680            randomLanguages.add(lang);
681            if(match.isCaptured(1))
682            {
683                lang = FakeLanguageGen.randomLanguage(rng.nextLong());
684                randomLanguages.add(lang);
685                do {
686                    latestGenerated = randomLanguages.get(0).word(rng, true, Math.min(rng.between(2, 5), rng.between(1, 5)))
687                            + "-" + randomLanguages.get(1).word(rng, true, Math.min(rng.between(2, 5), rng.between(1, 5)));
688                }while (latestGenerated.length() <= 5 || latestGenerated.length() >= 17);
689                dest.append(latestGenerated);
690            }
691            else
692            {
693                do{
694                    latestGenerated = lang.word(rng, true, Math.min(rng.between(2, 5), rng.between(1, 5)));
695                }while (latestGenerated.length() <= 2 || latestGenerated.length() >= 11);
696                dest.append(latestGenerated);
697            }
698        }
699    }
700
701    private class KnownLanguageSubstitution implements Substitution
702    {
703        public FakeLanguageGen language;
704        public KnownLanguageSubstitution(FakeLanguageGen lang)
705        {
706            language = lang;
707        }
708        @Override
709        public void appendSubstitution(MatchResult match, TextBuffer dest) {
710            if (match.isCaptured(1)) {
711                do
712                {
713                    latestGenerated = language.word(rng, true, Math.min(rng.between(2, 5), rng.between(1, 5))) +
714                            "-" + language.word(rng, true, Math.min(rng.between(2, 5), rng.between(1, 5)));
715                }while (latestGenerated.length() <= 5 || latestGenerated.length() >= 17);
716                dest.append(latestGenerated);
717            } else
718            {
719                do{
720                    latestGenerated = language.word(rng, true, Math.min(rng.between(2, 5), rng.between(1, 5)));
721                }while (latestGenerated.length() <= 2 || latestGenerated.length() >= 11);
722                dest.append(latestGenerated);
723            }
724        }
725    }
726
727    /**
728     * Generates a random possible name for a nation, such as "Iond-Gouccief Alliance" or "The Last Drayo Commonwealth".
729     * May use accented characters, as in
730     * "Thdsh-Hyttilb Hegemony" or "The Glorious Ch Empire"; if you want to strip these out and replace accented
731     * chars with their un-accented counterparts, you can use {@link FakeLanguageGen#removeAccents(CharSequence)}, which
732     * returns a CharSequence that can be converted to String if needed. Shortly after calling this method, but before
733     * calling it again, you can retrieve the generated random languages, if any were used while making nation names, by
734     * getting the FakeLanguageGen elements of this class' {@link #randomLanguages} field. Using one of these
735     * FakeLanguageGen objects, you can produce many more words with a similar style to the nation name, like "Drayo" in
736     * "The Last Drayo Commonwealth". If more than one language was used in the nation name, as in "Thdsh-Hyttilb
737     * Hegemony", you will have two languages in randomLanguages, so here "Thdsh" would be generated by the first
738     * language, and "Hyttilb" by the second language. Calling this method replaces the current contents of
739     * randomLanguages, so if you want to use those languages, get them while you can. This also assigns the
740     * {@link #latestGenerated} field to contain the part of the nation name without any larger titles; in the case of
741     * "The Glorious Ch Empire", the latestGenerated field would be assigned "Ch" at the same time the longer name
742     * would be returned. This field will be reassigned if this method is called again.
743     *
744     * @return a random name for a nation or a loose equivalent to a nation, as a String
745     */
746    public String makeNationName()
747    {
748        if(!this.mappings.containsKey("empire`noun`"))
749        {
750            addKnownCategories();
751        }
752        String working = process(rng.getRandomElement(nationTerms));
753        int frustration = 0;
754        while (frustration++ < 8 && similarFinder.matches(working))
755            working = process(rng.getRandomElement(nationTerms));
756        randomLanguages.clear();
757        RandomLanguageSubstitution sub = new RandomLanguageSubstitution();
758        Replacer replacer = Pattern.compile("@(-@)?").replacer(sub);
759        return replacer.replace(working);
760    }
761    /**
762     * Generates a random possible name for a nation, such as "Iond-Gouccief Alliance" or "The Last Drayo Commonwealth",
763     * with the FakeLanguageGen already available instead of randomly created. May use accented characters, as in
764     * "Thdsh Hegemony" or "The Glorious Ch Empire",
765     * if the given language can produce them; if you want to strip these out and replace accented chars
766     * with their un-accented counterparts, you can use {@link FakeLanguageGen#removeAccents(CharSequence)}, which
767     * returns a CharSequence that can be converted to String if needed, or simply get an accent-less language by
768     * calling {@link FakeLanguageGen#removeAccents()} on the FakeLanguageGen you would give this. This assigns the
769     * {@link #latestGenerated} field to contain the part of the nation name without any larger titles; in the case of
770     * "The Glorious Ch Empire", the latestGenerated field would be assigned "Ch" at the same time the longer name
771     * would be returned. This field will be reassigned if this method is called again.
772     * <br>
773     * Some nation names use a hyphenated pairing of what would normally be names in two different languages; if one of
774     * those names is produced by this it will produce two names in the same linguistic style. The randomLanguages field
775     * is not populated by this method; it is assumed that since you are passing this a FakeLanguageGen, you already
776     * have the one you want to use anyway.
777     *
778     * @param language a FakeLanguageGen that will be used to construct any non-English names
779     * @return a random name for a nation or a loose equivalent to a nation, as a String
780     */
781    public String makeNationName(FakeLanguageGen language)
782    {
783        if(!this.mappings.containsKey("empire`noun`"))
784        {
785            addKnownCategories();
786        }
787        String working = process(rng.getRandomElement(nationTerms));
788        int frustration = 0;
789        while (frustration++ < 8 && similarFinder.matches(working))
790            working = process(rng.getRandomElement(nationTerms));
791        randomLanguages.clear();
792        KnownLanguageSubstitution sub = new KnownLanguageSubstitution(language);
793        Replacer replacer = Pattern.compile("@(-@)?").replacer(sub);
794        return replacer.replace(working);
795    }
796
797    /**
798     * Generates a random possible name for a plant or tree, such as "Ikesheha's maple" or "sugarleaf birch".
799     * May use accented characters, as in "Ema's greenwood", if the given language can
800     * produce them; if you want to strip these out and replace accented chars with their un-accented counterparts, you
801     * can use {@link FakeLanguageGen#removeAccents(CharSequence)}, which returns a CharSequence that can be converted
802     * to String if needed. Shortly after calling this method, but before
803     * calling it again, you can retrieve the generated random languages, if any were used while making names, by
804     * getting the FakeLanguageGen elements of this class' {@link #randomLanguages} field. Using one of these
805     * FakeLanguageGen objects, you can produce many more words with a similar style to the person or place name, like
806     * "Drayo" in "The Last Drayo Commonwealth". Calling this method replaces the current contents of
807     * randomLanguages, so if you want to use those languages, get them while you can.
808     *
809     * @return a random name for a plant, shrub, or tree, as a String
810     */
811    public String makePlantName()
812    {
813        if(!this.mappings.containsKey("tree`noun`"))
814        {
815            addKnownCategories();
816        }
817        String working = process(plantTermShuffler.next());
818        int frustration = 0;
819        while (frustration++ < 8 && similarFinder.matches(working))
820            working = process(plantTermShuffler.next());
821        randomLanguages.clear();
822        RandomLanguageSubstitution sub = new RandomLanguageSubstitution();
823        Replacer replacer = Pattern.compile("@(-@)?").replacer(sub);
824        return replacer.replace(working).replace("\t", "");
825    }

1083    /**
1084     * Generates a random possible description for a potion in a container, such as "a smoky glass flask containing a
1085     * few drops of an orange tonic", "a milk carton filled with a red fluid", "a shining silver bottle filled with an
1086     * effervescent violet potion", or "a wineskin filled with a black serum".
1087     *
1088     * @return a random description for a potion or other liquid in a container
1089     */
1090    public String makePotionDescription()
1091    {
1092        if(!this.mappings.containsKey("liquid`noun`"))
1093        {
1094            addKnownCategories();
1095        }
1096        String working = process(potionTermShuffler.next());
1097        int frustration = 0;
1098        while (frustration++ < 8 && similarFinder.matches(working))
1099            working = process(potionTermShuffler.next());
1100        return StringKit.correctABeforeVowel(working);
1101    }
1102
1103    /**
1104     * Gets an English word for a given number, if this knows it. These words are known from 0 ("zero") to 20
1105     * ("twenty"), as well as some higher numbers. If a word isn't known for a number, this returns the number as a
1106     * String, such as "537" or "-1".
1107     * @param number the number to get a word for
1108     * @return the word associated with a number as a String, or if none is known, {@code String.valueOf(number)}.
1109     */
1110    public static String numberWord(final int number)
1111    {
1112        switch (number){
1113            case 0: return "zero";
1114            case 1: return "one";
1115            case 2: return "two";
1116            case 3: return "three";
1117            case 4: return "four";
1118            case 5: return "five";
1119            case 6: return "six";
1120            case 7: return "seven";
1121            case 8: return "eight";
1122            case 9: return "nine";
1123            case 10: return "ten";
1124            case 11: return "eleven";
1125            case 12: return "twelve";
1126            case 13: return "thirteen";
1127            case 14: return "fourteen";
1128            case 15: return "fifteen";
1129            case 16: return "sixteen";
1130            case 17: return "seventeen";
1131            case 18: return "eighteen";
1132            case 19: return "nineteen";
1133            case 20: return "twenty";
1134            case 30: return "thirty";
1135            case 40: return "fourty";
1136            case 50: return "fifty";
1137            case 60: return "sixty";
1138            case 70: return "seventy";
1139            case 80: return "eighty";
1140            case 90: return "ninety";
1141            case 100: return "hundred";
1142            case 1000: return "thousand";
1143            case 1000000: return "million";
1144            case 1000000000: return "billion";
1145            default: return String.valueOf(number);
1146        }
1147    }
1148
1149    /**
1150     * Gets an English word that describes a numbered position in some sequence, if this knows it (such as "second" or
1151     * "eleventh"). These words are known from 1 ("first") to 20 ("twentieth"), as well as some higher numbers. If a
1152     * word isn't known for a number, this appends a suffix based on the last base-10 digit to the number, as with "0th"
1153     * or "42nd".
1154     * @param number the number to get a position adjective for
1155     * @return the word associated with a number as a String, or if none is known, {@code String.valueOf(number)} followed by a two-char suffix from the last digit.
1156     */
1157    public static String numberAdjective(final int number)
1158    {
1159        switch (number){
1160            case 1: return "first";
1161            case 2: return "second";
1162            case 3: return "third";
1163            case 4: return "fourth";
1164            case 5: return "fifth";
1165            case 6: return "sixth";
1166            case 7: return "seventh";
1167            case 8: return "eighth";
1168            case 9: return "ninth";
1169            case 10: return "tenth";
1170            case 11: return "eleventh";
1171            case 12: return "twelfth";
1172            case 13: return "thirteenth";
1173            case 14: return "fourteenth";
1174            case 15: return "fifteenth";
1175            case 16: return "sixteenth";
1176            case 17: return "seventeenth";
1177            case 18: return "eighteenth";
1178            case 19: return "nineteenth";
1179            case 20: return "twentieth";
1180            case 30: return "thirtieth";
1181            case 40: return "fourtieth";
1182            case 50: return "fiftieth";
1183            case 60: return "sixtieth";
1184            case 70: return "seventieth";
1185            case 80: return "eightieth";
1186            case 90: return "ninetieth";
1187            case 100: return "hundredth";
1188            case 1000: return "thousandth";
1189            case 1000000: return "millionth";
1190            case 1000000000: return "billionth";
1191            default: 
1192            {
1193                switch (number % 10){
1194                    case 1: return number + "st";
1195                    case 2: return number + "nd";
1196                    case 3: return number + "rd";
1197                    default:return number + "th";
1198                }
1199            }
1200        }
1201    }
1202
1203    /**
1204     * Gets an English word for a number, if this knows it, where the number is chosen randomly between lowest and
1205     * highest, both inclusive. These words are known from 0 ("zero") to 20 ("twenty"), as well as some higher numbers.
1206     * If a word isn't known for a number, this returns the number as a String, such as "537" or "-1".
1207     * @param lowest the lower bound for numbers this can choose, inclusive
1208     * @param highest the upper bound for numbers this can choose, inclusive
1209     * @return a String word for a number in the given range, such as "six" or "eleven", if it is known
1210     */
1211    public String numberWordInRange(int lowest, int highest)
1212    {
1213        return numberWord(rng.nextSignedInt(highest + 1 - lowest) + lowest);
1214    }
1215    /**
1216     * Gets an English word that describes a numbered position in some sequence, if this knows it (such as "second" or
1217     * "eleventh"), where the number is chosen randomly between lowest and highest, both inclusive. These words are
1218     * known from 1 ("first") to 20 ("twentieth"), as well as some output for other numbers (such as "42nd" or "23rd").
1219     * @param lowest the lower bound for numbers this can choose, inclusive
1220     * @param highest the upper bound for numbers this can choose, inclusive
1221     * @return a String word for a number in the given range, such as "third" or "twelfth", if it is known
1222     */
1223    public String numberAdjectiveInRange(int lowest, int highest)
1224    {
1225        return numberAdjective(rng.nextSignedInt(highest + 1 - lowest) + lowest);
1226    }

1230            "Union`adj` Duchy`nouns` of @",  "The @ Duchy`noun`", "The Fancy`adj` @ Duchy`noun`", "The Sole`adj` @ Empire`noun`",
1231            "@ Empire`noun`", "@ Empire`noun`", "@ Empire`noun`", "@-@ Empire`noun`", "The Fancy`adj` @ Empire`noun`", "The Fancy`adj` @ Empire`noun`", "The Holy`adj` @ Empire`noun`");
1232

1566            makeList("heroines", "champions", "saviors", "crusaders", "knights", "maidens"),
1567            "popular`adj`",
1568            makeList("beloved", "adored", "revered", "worshipped"),
1569            "unpopular`adj`",
1570            makeList("reviled", "despised", "hated", "loathed"),
1571            "glyph`noun`",
1572            makeList("glyph", "sign", "symbol", "sigil", "seal", "mark"),
1573            "glyph`nouns`",
1574            makeList("glyphs", "signs", "symbols", "sigils", "seals", "marks"),
1575            "power`noun`",
1576            makeList("power", "force", "potency", "strength", "authority", "dominance"),
1577            "power`adj`",
1578            makeList("powerful", "forceful", "potent", "strong", "authoritative", "dominant"),
1579            "plant`term`",     plantTerms,
1580            "fruit`term`",     fruitTerms,
1581            "nut`term`",       nutTerms,
1582            "vegetable`term`", vegetableTerms,
1583            "flower`term`",    flowerTerms,
1584            "potion`term`",    potionTerms
1585            );
1586    public static final OrderedMap<String, ArrayList<String>>
1587            adjective = new OrderedMap<>(categories),
1588            noun = new OrderedMap<>(categories),
1589            nouns = new OrderedMap<>(categories);
1590    public static final OrderedMap<CharSequence, FakeLanguageGen> languages = new OrderedMap<CharSequence, FakeLanguageGen>(
1591            FakeLanguageGen.registeredNames.length, Hashers.caseInsensitiveStringHasher);
1592    static {
1593        for (int i = 0; i < FakeLanguageGen.registeredNames.length; i++) {
1594            languages.put(FakeLanguageGen.registeredNames[i].replace(' ', '_').toLowerCase() + "`gen`", FakeLanguageGen.registered[i]);
1595        }
1596    }

1648    /**
1649     * Thesaurus preset that changes all text to sound like this speaker: "Desaurus preset dat changez all text to sound
1650     * like dis speakah." You may be familiar with a certain sci-fi game that has orks who sound like this.
1651     */
1652    public static Thesaurus ORK = new Thesaurus("WAAAAAGH!");
1653
1654    /**
1655     * Thesaurus preset that sharply reduces the used letters to only: a, b, g, h, m, n, r, and z. This apparently is
1656     * the canonical set of letters that zombies can use? This will abuse the rules of proper English spelling, using r
1657     * and h as vowels, kind-of, in addition to a.
1658     */
1659    public static Thesaurus ZOMBIE = new Thesaurus("zrrmbrh grh BRRRNZ!");
1660
1661    static {
1662        ORK.alterations.add(new FakeLanguageGen.Alteration("\\bth", "d"));
1663        ORK.alterations.add(new FakeLanguageGen.Alteration("th", "dd"));
1664        ORK.alterations.add(new FakeLanguageGen.Alteration("er\\b", "ah"));
1665        ORK.alterations.add(new FakeLanguageGen.Alteration("es\\b", "ez"));
1666        ORK.addReplacement("the", "da")
1667                .addReplacement("their", "deyr")
1668                .addReplacement("yes", "ya")
1669                .addReplacement("your", "youse")
1670                .addReplacement("yours", "youses")
1671                .addReplacement("going", "gon'")
1672                .addReplacement("and", "an'")
1673                .addReplacement("to", "*snort*")
1674                .addReplacement("rhythm", "riddim")
1675                .addReplacement("get", "git")
1676                .addReplacement("good", "gud");
1677
1678        ZOMBIE.alterations.add(new FakeLanguageGen.Alteration("(?[[\\p{L}]-[A-Za-z]])", "r"));
1679        ZOMBIE.alterations.add(new FakeLanguageGen.Alteration("[pcst]h", "h"));
1680        ZOMBIE.alterations.add(new FakeLanguageGen.Alteration("[eiu]([tckhd]+)", "rh"));
1681        ZOMBIE.alterations.add(new FakeLanguageGen.Alteration("[aei][aeiy]", "aa"));
1682        ZOMBIE.alterations.add(new FakeLanguageGen.Alteration("o[hw]", "ah"));
1683        ZOMBIE.alterations.add(new FakeLanguageGen.Alteration("n[cdtkq]", "nh"));
1684        ZOMBIE.alterations.add(new FakeLanguageGen.Alteration("m\\b", "mm"));
1685        ZOMBIE.alterations.add(new FakeLanguageGen.Alteration("[td]+", "bh"));
1686        ZOMBIE.alterations.add(new FakeLanguageGen.Alteration("[ckq]+", "gh"));
1687        ZOMBIE.alterations.add(new FakeLanguageGen.Alteration("[ai]", "a"));
1688        ZOMBIE.alterations.add(new FakeLanguageGen.Alteration("[bvp]", "b"));
1689        ZOMBIE.alterations.add(new FakeLanguageGen.Alteration("[jg]", "g"));
1690        ZOMBIE.alterations.add(new FakeLanguageGen.Alteration("[fwyh]", "h"));
1691        ZOMBIE.alterations.add(new FakeLanguageGen.Alteration("[m]", "m"));
1692        ZOMBIE.alterations.add(new FakeLanguageGen.Alteration("[n]", "n"));
1693        ZOMBIE.alterations.add(new FakeLanguageGen.Alteration("[lreou]", "r"));
1694        ZOMBIE.alterations.add(new FakeLanguageGen.Alteration("[sxz]", "z"));
1695        ZOMBIE.alterations.add(new FakeLanguageGen.Alteration("([ahmnrz])\\b", "$1$1", 0.2));
1696        ZOMBIE.alterations.add(new FakeLanguageGen.Alteration("(\\b\\w+\\b)", "${!1}", 0.125));
1697    }
1698    static {
1699        
1700        // not related to ORK; this filters out synonyms that aren't in the appropriate list
1701        Iterator<String> it = adjective.keySet().iterator();
1702        while (it.hasNext()){
1703            if(!it.next().contains("`adj`"))
1704                it.remove();
1705        }
1706        it = noun.keySet().iterator();
1707        while (it.hasNext()){
1708            if(!it.next().contains("`noun`"))
1709                it.remove();
1710        }
1711        it = nouns.keySet().iterator();
1712        while (it.hasNext()){
1713            if(!it.next().contains("`nouns`"))
1714                it.remove();
1715        }
1716    }
1717
1718    /**
1719     * Gets a stable (large) String that stores all categories this version of Thesaurus knows, as well as all of the
1720     * words each category includes. This can be useful in conjunction with {@link #addArchivedCategories(String)} to
1721     * load a set of categories stored from an earlier version of SquidLib.
1722     * @return a category archive String that can be passed to {@link #addArchivedCategories(String)}
1723     */
1724    public static String archiveCategories(){
1725        return Converters.convertOrderedMap(
1726                        Converters.convertString,
1727                        Converters.convertArrayList(Converters.convertString)
1728                ).stringify(categories);
1729    }
1730
1731    /**
1732     * Gets a stable (large) String that stores all categories this version of Thesaurus knows, as well as all of the
1733     * words each category includes. This can be useful in conjunction with
1734     * {@link #addArchivedCategoriesAlternate(String)} to load a set of categories stored from an earlier version of
1735     * SquidLib, but its intended purpose is to provide a simpler format for archival that doesn't use {@link ObText}.
1736     * <br>
1737     * This yields a String that describes an OrderedMap of String keys (categories) mapped to ArrayList of String
1738     * values (the words each category knows). Each key-value pair is one line, typically separated by {@code "\n"} (but
1739     * because various OS properties can affect line endings, {@code "\r\n"} must also be handled). Items within the
1740     * line are separated by the non-breaking space character, Unicode 00A0. The first item on a line is the key, or the
1741     * category name. Remaining items are words the category knows. This may produce a trailing newline.
1742     * @return a category archive String that can be passed to {@link #addArchivedCategoriesAlternate(String)}
1743     */
1744    public static String archiveCategoriesAlternate(){
1745        StringBuilder sb = new StringBuilder(8192);
1746        for (int i = 0, n = categories.size(); i < n; i++) {
1747            sb.append(categories.keyAt(i)).append('\u00A0').append(StringKit.join("\u00A0", categories.getAt(i))).append('\n');
1748        }
1749        return sb.toString();
1750    }
1751}
